Ransomware.WannaHusky: WannaHusky is a Nim-compiled ransomware malware. Ransomware Wannahusky consists of multiple steps: The sample first returns the current directory of the user and then returns the home directory of the user. If cosmo.jpeg exists is on the Desktop of the infected host, the sample executes a PowerShell script (ps1.ps1). Next, the sample will encrypt cosmo.jpeg, adding the .WANNAHUSKY extension and write the WANNAHUSKY.png to the Desktop. The sample will then change the Desktop wallpaper to the WANNAHUSKY.png file. Lastly, it runs the tree C:\ command.  Malware sample provided by HuskyHacks as a part of their course, Practical Malware Analysis & Triage. https://medium.com/@mars0x/wannahusky-malware-analysis-w-yara-ttps- 2069fb479909
Ransomware.TinyCryptor: TinyCryptor is a ransomware deployed by threat actor OldGremlin, used for encrypting files in the infected system and holding it hostage for about $50,000. The group does not send their TinyCryptor ransomware directly by email; instead they first obtain remote access to the victim’s machine.  | Information on TinyCrypt | Ransomware Decr1pt Russian-speaking ransomware gang OldGremlin resumes attacks in Russia. https://blog.group-ib.com/oldgremlin_comeback
Ransomware.Quantum: Quantum is one of the fastest ransomware cases observed, in under four hours the threat actors went from initial access, to domain wide ransomware. The initial access vector for the ransomware is an IcedID payload delivered via email. Once the initial IcedID payload is executed, approximately 2 hours after initial infection, the threat actors appeared to begin hands-on-keyboard activity. Cobalt Strike and RDP were used to move across the network before using WMI and PsExec to deploy the Quantum ransomware. This case exemplified an extremely short Time-to-Ransom (TTR) of 3 hours and 44 minutes.  One of the fastest ransomware cases, ransomware deployed within 4 hours. https://thedfirreport.com/2022/04/25/quantum-ransomware/
Ransomware.XingLocker: XingLocker is a ransomware family that targets Windows systems. It is actually itself a re-branded version of the Mount Locker ransomware with a ransom note pointing the victim to a different onion service on the Tor network. Researchers observed a “franchise” RaaS model involving XingLocker, AstroLocker, and Mount Locker. In this model, there seems to be the main RaaS (in this case Mount Locker), and then affiliates license the ransomware and release it under their own name and brand.  | Xing Locker Old threat using same IcedID malware as initial vector as Quantum Ransomware. https://thedfirreport.com/2021/10/18/icedid-to-xinglocker-ransomware-in-24- hours/

Malware.Borat RAT: Borat RAT is a remote access trojan (RAT) that appeared on darknet markets in April 2022. The RAT offered easy-to-use features to conduct DDoS attacks, UAC bypass, and ransomware deployment. As a RAT, Borat enables remote threat actors to take complete control of their victim’s mouse and keyboard, access files, and network points, and hide any signs of their presence.  | Do you have any information on Borat? A new remote access trojan providing a wide range of functionalities. https://blog.cyble.com/2022/03/31/deep-dive-analysis-borat-rat/
Malware.CookieTime: CookieTime communicates with the C2 server using the HTTP protocol. In order to deliver the request type to the C2 server, it uses encoded cookie values and fetches command files from the C2 server.  Inactive backdoor observed in 2021 https://securelist.com/apt-trends-report-q1-2021/101967/
Malware.BIRDWATCH: BIRDWATCH is a .NET-based downloader that retrieves payloads over HTTP, writing them to disk and then executing them. BIRDWATCH uploads reconnaissance information from targeted systems as well, which includes running processes, software installed, network configuration, web browser information, and active directory data.  .NET-based downloader used by FIN7 and UNC3381 https://www.mandiant.com/resources/evolution-of-fin7
Malware.FOWLGAZE: FOWLGAZE is an updated version of BIRDWATCH downloader, used by FIN7.  A downloader used by FIN7 https://www.mandiant.com/resources/evolution-of-fin7
Malware.TAKEOUT: TAKEOUT is a downloader used by FIN7.  Downloader used by FIN7 https://www.mandiant.com/resources/evolution-of-fin7
Malware.SUPERSOFT: SUPERSOFT is a payload loaded by FIN7’s POWERTRASH.  Malware family used by FIN7 https://www.mandiant.com/resources/evolution-of-fin7
Malware.PILLOWMINT: PILLOWMINT is a Point-of-Sale malware tool used to scrape track 1 and track 2 payment card data from memory.  Malware family used by FIN7 https://www.mandiant.com/resources/evolution-of-fin7
Malware.EASYLOOK: EASYLOOK is a reconnaissance utility that FIN7 has used since at least 2019. EASYLOOK captures a wide range of data from infected systems, including operating system version, registration key, system name, username, domain information, and hardware specifications.  Reconnaissance utility used by FIN7 https://www.mandiant.com/resources/evolution-of-fin7
Malware.Octo: Octo is an evolved Android malware based on ExoCompact, a malware variant based on the Exo trojan that quit the cybercrime space and had its source code leaked in 2018. The remote access is provided through a live screen streaming module (updated every second) through Android’s MediaProjection and remote actions through the Accessibility Service. Octo uses a black screen overlay to hide the victim’s remote operations, sets screen brightness to zero, and disables all notifications by activating the “no interruption” mode. By making the device appear to be turned off, the malware can perform various tasks without the victim knowing. These tasks include screen taps, gestures, text writing, clipboard modification, data pasting, and scrolling up and down.  New Android banking malware remotely takes control of your device. https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/new-android-banking- malware-remotely-takes-control-of-your-device/
Malware.Barbie Downloader: Barb(ie) is a downloader component used by APT-C-23 to install the BarbWire backdoor. In the infection phase, the downloader is delivered alongside a video in a .rar file. The video is meant to distract the victim from the infection process that is happening in the background. Barbie Downloader / Barb(ie) Downloader / Barb(ie) /  | Barb(ie) Malware | Barbie Malware | What do you know about BarbieDownloader? Operation Bearded Barbie: APT-C-23 Campaign Targeting Israeli Officials https://www.cybereason.com/blog/operation-bearded-barbie-apt-c-23- campaign-targeting-israeli-officials
Malware.Sodamaster: Sodamaster is a backdoor, a tool believed to be used exclusively by the Stone Panda threat group since at least 2020. Sodamaster runs in the system memory (fileless) and is equipped to evade detection by looking in the registry for clues of a sandbox environment or by delaying its execution. The malware can also collect details about the system, search for running processes, and download and execute various payloads from the command and control server.  Chinese hackers, Cicada abuse VLC Media Player to launch malware loader. https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/chinese-hackers-abuse-vlc- media-player-to-launch-malware-loader/
Malware.Denonia: Denonia is the first publicly-known case of malware specifically designed to execute in an AWS Lambda environment. Researchers named this malware Denonia, after the name the attackers gave the domain it communicates with. The malware uses newer address resolution techniques for command and control traffic to evade typical detection measures and virtual network access controls. The early first samples ran crypto-mining software.  Cado Discovers Denonia: The First Malware Specifically Targeting Lambda. https://www.cadosecurity.com/cado-discovers-denonia-the-first-malware- specifically-targeting-lambda/
Malware.BEAKDROP: BEAKDROP is a loader used by FIN7.  A loader used by FIN7 https://www.mandiant.com/resources/evolution-of-fin7
Malware.Colibri: Colibri leverages PowerShell in a unique way to maintain persistence after a reboot. Depending on the Windows version, Colibri drops its copy in %APPDATA%\Local\ Microsoft\WindowsApps and names it Get-Variable.exe for Windows 10 and above, while for lower versions it drops it in %DOCUMENTS%/WindowsPowerShell named as dllhost.exe.  Colibri Loader combines Task Scheduler and PowerShell in clever persistence technique. https://blog.malwarebytes.com/threat-intelligence/2022/04/colibri-loader- combines-task-scheduler-and-powershell-in-clever-persistence-technique/
Malware.WINGNIGHT: WINGNIGHT is a WSF-based downloader that utilizes VBScript.  WSF-based downloader used by FIN7 and UNC3381 https://www.mandiant.com/resources/evolution-of-fin7
Malware.Parrot TDS: Parrot TDS, using tens of thousands of compromised websites, emerged in April
Malware.Industroyer2: Industroyer2 is a malware used to attack Ukraine’s power grid by threat actor SandWorm. It only implements the IEC-104 (aka IEC 60870-5-104) protocol to communicate with industrial equipment. This includes protection relays, used in electrical substations. This is a slight change from the 2016 Industroyer variant which is a fully-modular platform with payloads for multiple ICS protocols. Industroyer2 is highly configurable. It contains a detailed configuration hardcoded in its body, driving the malware actions. Industroyer2 is able to communicate with multiple devices at once.  Industroyer2: Industroyer reloaded This ICS-capable malware targets a Ukrainian energy company. https://www.welivesecurity.com/2022/04/12/industroyer2-industroyer-reloaded/
Malware.ARGUEPATCH: ARGUEPATCH is a patched version of a legitimate component of Hex-Rays IDA Pro software, specifically the remote IDA debugger server win32_remote.exe. IDA Pro is not intended to be used in an ICS environment, as its main purpose is for software reverse-engineering including malware analysis. It was however used by threat actor SandWorm in an attack on Power Grid in Ukraine.  Industroyer2: Industroyer reloaded This ICS-capable malware targets a Ukrainian energy company. https://www.welivesecurity.com/2022/04/12/industroyer2-industroyer-reloaded/
Malware.AWFULSHRED: AwfulShred is the Linux wiper used by threat actor Sandworm in their attack on a Power Grid in Ukraine. This Linux wiper is lightly obfuscated: variables and function names had been replaced with meaningless 8-letter words. The wiper destroys the whole content of the disks attached to the system by using shred if available or simply dd (with if=/dev/random) otherwise. If multiple disks are attached, data removal is done in parallel to speed up the process. Depending on the size, it may take hours for the full disk to be completely erased.  Industroyer2: Industroyer reloaded This ICS-capable malware targets a Ukrainian energy company. https://www.welivesecurity.com/2022/04/12/industroyer2-industroyer-reloaded/
Malware.POWERGAP: POWERGAP is a PowerShell script used to add a Group Policy that downloads file destructor components from a domain controller and creates a scheduled task on a computer. It was seen being used by threat actor SandWorm in their attack on Ukraine’s power grid.  Cyberattack by Sandworm Group (UAC-0082) on energy facilities of Ukraine using malicious programs INDUSTROYER2 and CADDYWIPER. https://cert.gov.ua/article/39518
Malware.PASSTEAL: Computers infected by PASSTEAL malware risk having compromised online accounts and losing stored personal information. Users may be in danger of financial loss, identity theft, and reputation compromise.  Old threat, added in the KB. https://www.trendmicro.com/vinfo/hk-en/threat-encyclopedia/web-attack/153/ pixsteal-and-passteal-sport-new-ways-to-steal-data
Malware.EVILSCHOLAR: EVILSCHOLAR is a capability designed to discover, access, manipulate, and disable Schneider Electric PLCs. A framework that communicates using Modbus - one of the most common industrial protocols - and Codesys. EVILSCHOLAR contains modules to interact with, scan, and attack at least three Schneider Electric programmable logic controllers (PLCs).  | Give information on EVIL SCHOLAR | CODECALL | Malware CODE CALL New State-Sponsored Cyber Attack Tools Target Multiple Industrial Control Systems https://hub.dragos.com/hubfs/116-Whitepapers/Dragos_ChernoviteWP_v2b. pdf?hsLang=en
Malware.MOUSEHOLE: MOUSEHOLE is a tool that scans for OPC servers, enumerates OPC structure/tags, brute forces credentials, and reads/writes OPC tag values.  | Malware MOUSE HOLE | What is TAGRUN? | TAG RUN New State-Sponsored Cyber Attack Tools Target Multiple Industrial Control Systems https://hub.dragos.com/hubfs/116-Whitepapers/Dragos_ChernoviteWP_v2b. pdf?hsLang=en
Malware.EnemyBot: EnemyBot is mainly derived from Gafgyt’s source code but has been observed to borrow several modules from Mirai’s original source code. It uses several methods of obfuscation for its strings to hinder analysis and hides itself from other botnets. Furthermore, it connects to a command-and-control (C2) server that is hidden in the Tor network, making its takedown more complicated. Enemybot has been seen targeting routers from Seowon Intech, D-Link, and exploits a recently reported iRZ router vulnerability to infect more devices.  Keksec’s Latest DDoS Botnet https://www.fortinet.com/blog/threat-research/enemybot-a-look-into-keksecs- latest-ddos-botnet
Malware.Fendr: Fendr, also called ExMatter is a custom tool for exfiltration which has only been observed in threat actor BlackMatter activity. The group attempted to deploy the malware extensively within organizations in December 2021 and January 2022. BlackMatter prioritized collection of sensitive information with Fendr to successfully support their scheme of double coercion. In addition, the modification of this reused tool demonstrates a more sophisticated planning and development regimen for adapting requirements to target environments, characteristic of a maturing criminal enterprise.  | Information on ExMatter Custom made tool used by BlackCat Ransomware Group. https://securelist.com/a-bad-luck-blackcat/106254/
Malware.TinyFluff: TinyFluff is a successor to the threat actor OldGremlin’s custom backdoor called TinyNode, which OldGremlin used as the primary downloader for receiving and running malicious scripts. The purpose of TinyFluff is to launch the interpreter Node. js on the infected device and grant remote access to it.  | Tiny Fluff information Russian-speaking ransomware gang OldGremlin resumes attacks in Russia. https://blog.group-ib.com/oldgremlin_comeback
Malware.WebFluff: Malware used by threat actor OldGremlin in their financially motivated attack campaigns.  Russian-speaking ransomware gang OldGremlin resumes attacks in Russia. https://blog.group-ib.com/oldgremlin_comeback
Malware.VPNFILTER: A malware family used by Russia-nexus threat actors to target ICS assets and data.  Malware used in attacking industrial control systems. https://www.mandiant.com/resources/incontroller-state-sponsored-ics-tool
Malware.ExoCrypt: The malware author responsible for ZingoStealer also offers a crypter service that allows ZingoStealer users to obtain encrypted ZingoStealer builds that assist with evading endpoint detection on systems. This crypter is called ExoCrypt.  Threat Spotlight: “Haskers Gang” Introduces New ZingoStealer https://blog.talosintelligence.com/2022/04/haskers-gang-zingostealer.html
Malware.GZipLoader: GZipLoader is the loader component of the IcedID infection chain. Its purpose is to download and execute the final encrypted payload from the control panel. The encrypted payload mimics a GZIP file, which is why it is called GZipLoader.  A new IcedID GZipLoader variant https://threatray.com/blog/a-new-icedid-gziploader-variant/
Malware.Inno Stealer: The capabilities of Inno Stealer are typical for this kind of malware, including collecting web browser cookies and stored credentials, data in cryptocurrency wallets, and data from the filesystem. The set of targeted browsers and crypto wallets is extensive, including Chrome, Edge, Brave, Opera, Vivaldi, 360 Browser, and Comodo. An interesting characteristic of Inno Stealer is that the network management and the data-stealing functions are multi-threaded. All stolen data is copied via a PowerShell command to the user’s temporay directory, encrypted, and later sent to the operator’s command and control server. Researchers named it “Inno Stealer” due to its use of the Inno Setup Windows installer.  New information stealer that uses the Inno Setup Windows installer. https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/unofficial-windows-11- upgrade-installs-info-stealing-malware/
Malware.DAFOM: DAFOM is a malicious application that purports to be a “cryptocurrency portfolio application.” It had a Mach-O binary packaged within the Electron application was signed by an Apple digital signature issued for the Apple Developer Team W58CYKFH67. The certificate associated with Apple Developer Team W58CYKFH67 has been revoked. This malicious application is a part of TraderTraitor.  Malicious Application, a part of TraderTraitor. https://www.ic3.gov/Media/News/2022/220418.pdf
Malware.CryptAIS: CryptAIS uses the same language as TokenAIS to advertise that it “helps build a portfolio of AI-based trading.” It is distributed as an Apple Disk Image (DMG) file that is digitally signed by an Apple digital signature issued for the Apple Developer Team CMHD64V5R8 whose certificate has been revoked. This application is a part of TraitorTrader that’s function passes the email address that the user provided and the system platform to the C2 server, decrypts the response using AES 256 in CTR mode and a key provided in the response, then writes the decrypted data to a file and executes it in a new shell.  Malicious Application, a part of TraderTraitor. https://www.ic3.gov/Media/News/2022/220418.pdf
Malware.Esilet: Esilet claims to offer live cryptocurrency prices and price predictions. It contains a simpler version of TraderTraitor code. Esilet has been observed delivering payloads of at least two different macOS variants of Manuscrypt.  Malicious Application, a part of TraderTraitor. https://www.ic3.gov/Media/News/2022/220418.pdf
Malware.LookBack Backdoor: The LookBack backdoor utilized by TA410 uses a custom network protocol, which can function over HTTP or raw TCP, for C&C server communications.  | Anything on Look Back Backdoor | Malware LookBack ESET researchers reveal a detailed profile of TA410: they believe this cyberespionage umbrella group consists of three different teams using different toolsets, including a new version of the FlowCloud espionage backdoor discovered by ESET. https://www.welivesecurity.com/2022/04/27/lookback-ta410-umbrella- cyberespionage-ttps-activity/
Malware.ECCENTRICBANDWAGON: This family of malware is used as a reconnaissance tool. ECCENTRICBANDWAGON is used for keylogging and screen capture functionality. The malware samples found by researchers were very similar but differed slightly in the location where they stored the key logs and screenshots. Some variants had RC4 encrypted strings within the executable and conduct a simple, ineffective cleanup, whereas others did not.  | ECCENTRIC BANDWAGON Malware used by threat actor, BeagleBoyz. https://www.cisa.gov/uscert/ncas/analysis-reports/ar20-239a
Malware.DoubleZero: DoubleZero is a .NET-based malware that destroys files and registry keys on the infected system, according to the researchers. The malware first destroys non-system files and then system-related files. Before shutting down the system, DoubleZero destroys the following Windows registry branches: HKCU, HKU, HKLM, HKLM\BCD.  | What do you mean by Double Zero? Malware used against Ukraine. https://therecord.media/a-deeper-look-at-the-malware-being-used-on- ukrainian-targets/
Malware.Fantasy Injector: Fantasy is the first of a two-part process for deploying GOLDBACKDOOR. Both parts are written in position-independent code (shellcode) containing an embedded payload, and use process injection to deploy GOLDBACKDOOR.  | Details on Fantasy North Korean hackers targeting journalists with novel malware. https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/north-korean-hackers- targeting-journalists-with-novel-malware/
Malware.X4: X4 is a custom backdoor that is used as a first stage payload before LookBack is deployed. It is loaded by a VMProtect-ed loader, usually named PortableDeviceApi.dll or WptsExtensions.dll.  ESET researchers reveal a detailed profile of TA410: they believe this cyberespionage umbrella group consists of three different teams using different toolsets, including a new version of the FlowCloud espionage backdoor discovered by ESET. https://www.welivesecurity.com/2022/04/27/lookback-ta410-umbrella- cyberespionage-ttps-activity/
Malware.AppleJeus: A Crypto stealing malware used by threat actor Lazarus Group to target cryptocurrency exchanges, finance service companies and similar entities.  | Details about Apple Jeus AppleJeus: Analysis of North Korea’s Cryptocurrency Malware, Old threat, added in the KB. https://www.cisa.gov/uscert/ncas/alerts/aa21-048a
Malware.Royal Road: Royal Road is a malicious document builder used by several cyberespionage groups. Files built with this tool are RTF documents exploiting Equation Editor N-day vulnerabilities such as CVE-2017-11882. TA410 operators also use the Royal Road.  | Details on Royal Road ESET researchers reveal a detailed profile of TA410: they believe this cyberespionage umbrella group consists of three different teams using different toolsets, including a new version of the FlowCloud espionage backdoor discovered by ESET. https://www.welivesecurity.com/2022/04/27/lookback-ta410-umbrella- cyberespionage-ttps-activity/
Malware.Fire Chili: Fire Chili is a rootkit that starts by ensuring that the victim machine is not running in safe mode. It then checks the operating system version. The rootkit uses Direct Kernel Object Modification (DKOM), which involves undocumented kernel structures and objects, for its operations. For this reason, it relies on specific OS builds as otherwise, it may cause the infected machine to crash.  |  | What can you tell me about Acid Rain? AcidRain: A Modem Wiper Rains Down on Europe
Malware.BlackGuard: BlackGuard is an information-stealing malware. The stealer can snatch sensitive information from a broad range of applications, pack everything in a ZIP archive and send it to the C2 of the malware-as-a-service (MaaS) operation. Threat actors who purchased the subscription can then access the BlackGuard web panel to retrieve the stolen data logs, either exploiting them themselves or selling them to others.  | What can you tell me about Black Guard? New BlackGuard password-stealing malware sold on hacker forums. https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/new-blackguard-password- stealing-malware-sold-on-hacker-forums/ Borat RAT Borat RAT is a remote access trojan (RAT) that appeared on darknet markets in April 2022. The RAT offered easy-to-use features to conduct DDoS attacks, UAC bypass, and ransomware deployment. As a RAT, Borat enables remote threat actors to take complete control of their victim’s mouse and keyboard, access files, and network points, and hide any signs of their presence.  | Do you have any information on Borat? A new remote access trojan providing a wide range of functionalities. https://blog.cyble.com/2022/03/31/deep-dive-analysis-borat-rat/
Malware.Beastmode: Beastmode is a Mirai-based distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) botnet. By taking control of the vulnerable routers, Beastmode has access to hardware resources that allow it to launch DDoS attacks. The botnet operators make money either by selling DDoS services or by launching attacks against firms and asking for a ransom to stop.  | B3astmode A new Mirai-based DDoS https://www.fortinet.com/blog/threat-research/totolink-vulnerabilities- beastmode-mirai-campaign
Malware.POWERPLANT: POWERPLANT, also referred to as KillACK, is a PowerShell-based backdoor with a breadth of capabilities. It is a vast backdoor framework that contains internal version identifiers within the code. POWERPLANT servers also send multiple additional module types as “tasks” for target systems to execute.  | killack PowerShell-based backdoor used by FIN7 https://www.mandiant.com/resources/evolution-of-fin7
Malware.CROWVIEW: CROWVIEW is .NET-based downloader, that can house an embedded payload, self- delete, support additional arguments, and store a slightly different configuration from BIRDWATCH.  .NET-based downloader used by FIN7 https://www.mandiant.com/resources/evolution-of-fin7
Malware.LOADOUT: LOADOUT is an obfuscated VBScript-based downloader that harvests extensive information from the infected system. The harvested information is then sent to a command-and-control (C2) server.  VBScript-based downloader used by FIN7 https://www.mandiant.com/resources/evolution-of-fin7
Malware.POWERTRASH: POWERTRASH is an in-memory dropper, or loader, written in PowerShell that executes an embedded payload. Observed payloads loaded by FIN7’s POWERTRASH include CARBANAK, DICELOADER, SUPERSOFT, BEACON, and PILLOWMINT. POWERTRASH is a uniquely obfuscated iteration of a shellcode invoker included in the PowerSploit framework available on GitHub.  PowerShell-based downloader used by FIN7 https://www.mandiant.com/resources/evolution-of-fin7
Malware.BEACON: BEACON has been used as a secondary mode of access by FIN7, alongside some POWERPLANT infections.  Malware family used by FIN7 https://www.mandiant.com/resources/evolution-of-fin7
Malware.BOATLAUNCH: BOATLAUNCH is a utility sent from FIN7 POWERPLANT controllers that is used as a helper module during intrusion operations. BOATLAUNCH is used to patch PowerShell processes on infected systems to bypass Windows AntiMalware Scan Interface (AMSI).  Malware utility used by FIN7 https://www.mandiant.com/resources/evolution-of-fin7
Malware.STONEBOAT: STONEBOAT is a .NET-based in-memory dropper that decrypts a shellcode payload embedded in it. The payload is then mapped into memory and executed. STONEBOAT was observed first loading an intermediary loader called DAVESHELL, which then executed the final DICELOADER payload.  .NET based dropper used by FIN7 https://www.mandiant.com/resources/evolution-of-fin7
Malware.FLYHIGH: FLYHIGH is a downloader written in C using the Excel XLL SDK, but masquerades as using the Excel-DNA framework.  C-based downloader used by FIN7 and UNC3381 https://www.mandiant.com/resources/evolution-of-fin7
Malware.Process Manager: Process Manager is an Android malware that can record your audio, track locations, send or read texts, and even access your storage to use the camera or see pictures. To make matters worse, the Process Manager malware employs a gear-shaped icon, so it looks like a system Settings app, enabling it to hide on a user’s device easily. This Android malware doesn’t hide in plain sight either, as users would see a persistent notification that “Process Manager” is running. It looks all official, but it’s certainly not good.  Newly found Android malware records audio, tracks your location https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/newly-found-android- malware-records-audio-tracks-your-location/
Malware.FFDroider: FFDroider is an information stealer that emerged in 2022, stealing credentials and cookies stored in browsers to hijack victims’ social media accounts. Like many malware, FFDroider is spread through software cracks, free software, games, and other files downloaded from torrent sites. When installing these downloads, FFDroider will also be installed, but disguised as the Telegram desktop app to evade detection. Once launched, the malware will create a Windows registry key named “FFDroider,” which led to the naming of this malware.  New FFDroider malware steals Facebook, Instagram, Twitter accounts. https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/new-ffdroider-malware- steals-facebook-instagram-twitter-accounts/
Malware.BarbWire Backdoor: BarbWire is a backdoor component of APT-C-23’s operation. It is a very capable piece of malware, a lot of effort was put into hiding its capabilities using a custom base64 algorithm. Its main goal is to fully compromise the victim machine, gaining access to their most sensitive data. The backdoor’s main capabilities include: Persistence, OS Reconnaissance, Data encryption, Keylogging, Screen capturing, Audio recording, Download additional malware, Local/external drives, and directory enumeration, Steal specific file types and exfiltrating data.  | BarbWire Operation Bearded Barbie: APT-C-23 Campaign Targeting Israeli Officials https://www.cybereason.com/blog/operation-bearded-barbie-apt-c-23- campaign-targeting-israeli-officials
Malware.VolatileVenom: VolatileVenom is one of APT-C-23’s arsenal of Android malware. The attackers lure the victims into installing the VolatileVenom under the pretext that the suggested app is more “secure” and “discrete.” Based on research, it seems that VolatileVenom has been operationalized and integrated into the group’s arsenal since at least April of 2020, and disguises itself using icons and names of chat applications.  | Information on Volatile Venom Operation Bearded Barbie: APT-C-23 Campaign Targeting Israeli Officials https://www.cybereason.com/blog/operation-bearded-barbie-apt-c-23- campaign-targeting-israeli-officials
Malware.Elephant Framework: Elephant is a malware framework written in Go. The activity has been attributed to UAC-0056 (TA471, SaintBear, UNC2589) by CERT-UA. The malware that is dropped by the phishing lure is the dropper component of what researchers call the “Elephant Framework.” The framework consists of four components that work in unison.  | Malware Elephant Elephant Framework Delivered in Phishing Attacks Against Ukrainian Organizations Elephant Framework Delivered in Phishing Attacks Against Ukrainian Organizations
Malware.META: META is one of the novel info-stealers, along with Mars Stealer and BlackGuard, whose operators wish to take advantage of Raccoon Stealer’s exit from the market that left many searching for their next platform. The tool is sold at $125 for monthly subscribers or $1,000 for unlimited lifetime use and is promoted as an improved version of RedLine. META modifies Windows Defender via PowerShell to exclude .exe files from scanning, to protect its files from detection.  New Meta information stealer distributed in malspam campaign https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/new-meta-information- stealer-distributed-in-malspam-campaign/
Malware.FakeCalls: FakeCalls is a banking trojan for Android that comes with a powerful capability that enables it to take over calls to a bank’s customer support number and connect the victim directly with the cybercriminals operating the malware. Disguised as a mobile app from a popular bank, FakeCalls displays all the marks of the entity it impersonates, including the official logo and the customer support number. When the victim tries to call the bank, the malware breaks the connection and shows its call screen, which is almost indistinguishable from the real one. While the victim sees the bank’s real number on the screen, the connection is to the cybercriminals, who can pose as the bank’s customer support representatives and obtain details that would give them access to the victim’s funds. FakeCalls mobile banking trojan can do this because at the moment of installation it asks for several permissions that give it access to the contact list, microphone, camera, geolocation, and call handling.  | Anything on Fake Calls Android banking malware intercepts calls to customer support. https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/android-banking-malware- intercepts-calls-to-customer-support/
Malware.Industroyer: Industroyer is the first known malware specifically designed to attack electrical grids. Industroyer is a modular framework consisting of a main backdoor, a service launcher component, four payload components, and several additional helper modules. It was used by threat actor SandWorm to attack Ukraine’s power grid.  Industroyer2: Industroyer reloaded This ICS-capable malware targets a Ukrainian energy company. https://www.welivesecurity.com/2022/04/12/industroyer2-industroyer-reloaded/
Malware.TailJump: Malware used by threat actor SandWorm in deploying attacks on Power Grid in Ukraine. TailJump is also known to be an encrypted version of CaddyWiper.  | Malware Tail Jump Industroyer2: Industroyer reloaded This ICS-capable malware targets a Ukrainian energy company. https://www.welivesecurity.com/2022/04/12/industroyer2-industroyer-reloaded/
Malware.ORCSHRED: ORCSHRED is a worm written in Bash. This Bash script starts by adding a scheduled task (cron job) to launch a wiper component unless it was launched with the “owner” argument. This is likely a way to avoid the initial system used to launch the worm auto-destructing. The worm was used by threat actor Sandworm in their attack campaign against Ukraine.  Industroyer2: Industroyer reloaded This ICS-capable malware targets a Ukrainian energy company. https://www.welivesecurity.com/2022/04/12/industroyer2-industroyer-reloaded/
Malware.SOLOSHRED: SOLOSHRED is a Solaris wiper written in Bash. It was seen by researchers being used in attack on Ukraine’s power grid. The malicious script iterates overall services to stop and disable them if they contain the keyword ssh, http, apache and additionally ora_ or oracle, these services are very likely used by applications used to control ICS systems. Wiping them would prevent the energy company’s operators from retaking control of the substations.  Industroyer2: Industroyer reloaded This ICS-capable malware targets a Ukrainian energy company. https://www.welivesecurity.com/2022/04/12/industroyer2-industroyer-reloaded/
Malware.Tarrask: Tarrask creates “hidden” scheduled tasks, and subsequent actions to remove the task attributes, to conceal the scheduled tasks from traditional means of identification.  Tarrask malware uses scheduled tasks for defense evasion https://www.microsoft.com/security/blog/2022/04/12/tarrask-malware-uses- scheduled-tasks-for-defense-evasion/
Malware.PIPEDREAM: PIPEDREAM, also known as INCONTROLLER, is the seventh known Industrial Control Systems (ICS)-specific malware and fifth specifically developed to disrupt industrial processes. PIPEDREAM demonstrates significant adversary research and development focused on disruption, degradation, and potential destruction of the industrial environment and physical processes. It can disrupt, degrade, and potentially destroy industrial environments and processes. PIPEDREAM can impact a wide variety of Programmable Logic Controllers (PLCs) and industrial software, including specific Omron and Schneider Electric PLCs, and Open Platform Communications Unified Architecture (OPC UA) servers.  | PIPE DREAM Malware | What is INCONTROLLER? New State-Sponsored Cyber Attack Tools Target Multiple Industrial Control Systems https://hub.dragos.com/hubfs/116-Whitepapers/Dragos_ChernoviteWP_v2b. pdf?hsLang=en
Malware.DUSTTUNNEL: NCustom remote operational implant capability to perform host reconnaissance and command and control.  | Malware DUST TUNNEL New State-Sponsored Cyber Attack Tools Target Multiple Industrial Control Systems https://hub.dragos.com/hubfs/116-Whitepapers/Dragos_ChernoviteWP_v2b. pdf?hsLang=en
Malware.BADOMEN: BADOMEN is a remote shell capability designed to interact with Omron software and PLCs. A framework with capabilities to interact with and scan some types of Omron PLCs via HTTP, Telnet, and Omron FINS protocol. The tool can also interact with Omron’s servo drives, which use feedback control to deliver energy to motors for precision motion control.  | Information on OMSHELL | BAD OMEN New State-Sponsored Cyber Attack Tools Target Multiple Industrial Control Systems https://hub.dragos.com/hubfs/116-Whitepapers/Dragos_ChernoviteWP_v2b. pdf?hsLang=en
Malware.LAZYCARGO: LAZYCARGO is a capability that drops and exploits a vulnerable ASRock driver to load an unsigned driver.  | Anything on LAZY CARGO New State-Sponsored Cyber Attack Tools Target Multiple Industrial Control Systems https://hub.dragos.com/hubfs/116-Whitepapers/Dragos_ChernoviteWP_v2b. pdf?hsLang=en
Malware.Fodcha: Researchers named the botnet Fodcha because of its initial use of the C2 domain name folded in and its use of the chacha algorithm to encrypt network traffic. Fodcha mainly spreads through NDay vulnerabilities and Telnet/SSH weak passwords. Fodcha’s function is simple. When it executes on the compromised device, it first checks the runtime parameters. When there are no parameters, it exits out. Fodcha does this as a simple countermeasure to deter sandbox. When parameters are present, it first decrypts the key configurations data, the data include some sensitive information such as C2s will It then prints “here we are” on the Console, and uses a random string to disguise the process name. Finally, communication with the C2 is established.  A new DDos botnet https://blog.netlab.360.com/fodcha-a-new-ddos-botnet/
Malware.Zhadnost: Zhadnost is a botnet of more than 3,000 unique IP addresses, across multiple countries and continents, that are the source of the DDoS attacks which consisted of HTTP floods and DNS amplification. Zhadnost is Russian for “Greed.” meaning the botnet is likely orchestrated by Russian or pro-Russian actors. Most Zhadnost bots are routers, the majority of them MikroTik, with misconfigured DNS recursion settings and other known vulnerabilities.  Zhadnost DDoS botnet deployed against Finland https://www.computerweekly.com/news/252515952/Zhadnost-DDoS-botnet- deployed-against-Finland
Malware.TinyNode: TinyNode is a predecessor to threat actor, OldGremlin’s custom backdoor called TinyFluff, which OldGremlin used as the primary downloader for receiving and running malicious scripts.  | Tiny Node Russian-speaking ransomware gang OldGremlin resumes attacks in Russia. https://blog.group-ib.com/oldgremlin_comeback
Malware.TinyPosh: TinyPosh, a custom Trojan developed by threat actor OldGremlin.  Russian-speaking ransomware gang OldGremlin resumes attacks in Russia. https://blog.group-ib.com/oldgremlin_comeback
Malware.PEACEPIPE: A malware family used by Russia-nexus threat actors to target ICS assets and data.  Malware used in attacking industrial control systems. https://www.mandiant.com/resources/incontroller-state-sponsored-ics-tool
Malware.ZingoStealer: ZingoStealer is an information stealer which was first introduced to the wild in March 2022. The malware leverages Telegram chat features to facilitate malware executable build delivery and data exfiltration. ZingoStealer can exfiltrate sensitive information such as credentials, steal cryptocurrency wallet information, and mine cryptocurrency on victims’ systems, while this stealer is freely available and can be used by multiple threat actors, researchers have observed a focus on infecting Russian speaking victims under the guise of game cheats, key generators and pirated software, which likely indicates a current focus on home users.  | Give information on Zingo Stealer Threat Spotlight: “Haskers Gang” Introduces New ZingoStealer https://blog.talosintelligence.com/2022/04/haskers-gang-zingostealer.html
Malware.Polazert: Polazert is a Trojan, specifically designed to steal credentials from browsers and provide the attacker with a backdoor to further compromise infected systems. To achieve this, collected data is sent to the C&C server.  An old threat, related to SolarMarker which is recently active. https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/solarmarke
Malware.TraderTraitor: The term TraderTraitor describes a series of malicious applications written using cross-platform JavaScript code with the Node.js runtime environment using the Electron framework. The malicious applications are derived from a variety of open- source projects and purport to be cryptocurrency trading or price prediction tools, namely, DAFOM, TokenAIS, CryptAIS, AlticGO, Esilet, and CreAI Deck.  | Details about Trader Traitor TraderTraitor: North Korean State-Sponsored APT Targets Blockchain Companies https://www.ic3.gov/Media/News/2022/220418.pdf
Malware.TokenAIS: TokenAIS purports to help “build a portfolio of AI-based trading” for cryptocurrencies. Mach-O binaries packaged within the Electron application contained an Apple digital signature issued for the Apple Developer Team RN4BTXA4SA. The certificate associated with Apple Developer Team RN4BTXA4SA has been revoked. This malicious application is a part of TraderTraitor’s malicious apps. The TraderTraitor function passes the email address that the user provided and the system platform to the C2 server, decrypts the response using AES 256 in CBC mode with a hardcoded initialization vector and a key provided in the response, then writes the decrypted data to a file and executes it in a new shell.  Malicious Application, a part of TraderTraitor. https://www.ic3.gov/Media/News/2022/220418.pdf
Malware.AlticGO: AlticGO was observed packaged as Nullsoft Scriptable Install System (NSIS) Windows executables that extracted an Electron application packaged for Windows. These executables contain a simpler version of TraderTraitor code.  | A part of TraderTraitor. Malicious Application, a part of TraderTraitor. https://www.ic3.gov/Media/News/2022/220418.pdf
Malware.CreAI Deck: CreAI Deck claims to be a platform for “artificial intelligence and deep learning.” No droppers for it were identified, but the filenames of the samples, win32.bin, and darwin64.bin, match the naming conventions used by other versions of TraderTraitor when downloading a payload. Both are samples of Manuscrypt that contact for C2 using HTTP POST requests with multipart/form-data Content-Types.  | CreAIDeck Malicious Application, a part of TraderTraitor. https://www.ic3.gov/Media/News/2022/220418.pdf
Malware.Ants2Whale: In late 2020, a new version of AppleJeus was identified called “Ants2Whale.” The website shows a legitimate-looking cryptocurrency company and application. The website contains multiple spelling and grammar mistakes indicating the creator may not have English as a first language. The website states that to download Ants2Whale, a user must contact the administrator, as their product is a “premium package”.  AppleJeus: Analysis of North Korea’s Cryptocurrency Malware, Old threat, added in the KB. https://www.cisa.gov/uscert/ncas/alerts/aa21-048a
Malware.Lillin scanner: Lillin scanner is a variant of BotenaGo that appears to have derived from the leaked source code. The sample they analyzed targeted Lilin security camera DVR devices, which prompted the researchers to name it the “Lillin scanner”. The source code of the BotenaGo malware was leaked in October 2021, which led to the creation of new variants based on the original. Lillin scanner differs from BotenaGo in that it doesn’t check the banner for the given IPs. It is possible that this tool is chained with another program that builds lists of Lilin devices using services like Shodan or other mass scanning tools. The Lillin scanner contains 11 pairs of user-password credentials in its code. These credentials are Base64-encoded to be used in the basic authentication needed to exploit the vulnerability that allows the Remote Code Execution (RCE).  | Malware Lillin BotenaGo New BotenaGo Variant Discovered by Nozomi Networks Labs. https://www.nozominetworks.com/blog/new-botenago-variant-discovered-by- nozomi-networks-labs/
Malware.Prynt Stealer: Prynt Stealer offers powerful capabilities and extra keylogger and clipper modules. It targets a large selection of web browsers, messaging apps, and gaming apps and can also perform direct financial compromise. Its authors sell the tool in time-based subscriptions, such as 100$/month, $200/quarter, or $700 for a year, but it is also sold under a lifetime license for $900. Additionally, buyers may take advantage of the malware’s builder to create a specialized, lean, and hard-to-detect spin of Prynt to be deployed in targeted operations.  | What is Prynt? New powerful Prynt Stealer malware sells for just $100 per month https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/new-powerful-prynt-stealer- malware-sells-for-just-100-per-month/
Malware.GOLDBACKDOOR: Goldbackdoor is executed as a PE file (portable executable) and can accept basic commands remotely and exfiltrate data. For this, it comes with a set of API keys that it uses to authenticate to Azure and retrieve commands for execution. These commands are related to keylogging, file operations, basic RCE, and the ability to uninstall itself. The malware utilizes legitimate cloud services for the exfiltration of files, like Google Drive and Microsoft OneDrive. The files targeted by Goldbackdoor are mainly documents and media, like PDF, DOCX, MP3, TXT, M4A, JPC, XLS, PPT, BIN, 3GP, and MSG.  | Tell me something about Gold Backdoor North Korean hackers targeting journalists with novel malware. https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/north-korean-hackers- targeting-journalists-with-novel-malware/
Malware.FlowCloud: FlowCloud is a complex and modular C++ RAT. It has several interesting capabilities, including 1) Controlling connected microphones and triggering recording when sound levels above a specified threshold volume are detected. 2) Monitoring clipboard events to steal clipboard content. 3) Monitoring file system events to collect new and modified files and 4) controlling attached camera devices to take pictures of the compromised computer’s surroundings.  | Information on Flow Cloud ESET researchers reveal a detailed profile of TA410: they believe this cyberespionage umbrella group consists of three different teams using different toolsets, including a new version of the FlowCloud espionage backdoor discovered by ESET. https://www.welivesecurity.com/2022/04/27/lookback-ta410-umbrella- cyberespionage-ttps-activity/
Malware.Tendyron: Threat Actor FlowingFrog uses a first-stage payload that researchers have named the Tendyron downloader. Tendyron.exe is a legitimate executable, signed by online- banking security vendor Tendyron Corporation, and is vulnerable to DLL search order hijacking. Persistence for the downloaded payload is established via the Tendyron value under the Run key HKCU\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run.  ESET researchers reveal a detailed profile of TA410: they believe this cyberespionage umbrella group consists of three different teams using different toolsets, including a new version of the FlowCloud espionage backdoor discovered by ESET. https://www.welivesecurity.com/2022/04/27/lookback-ta410-umbrella- cyberespionage-ttps-activity/
Malware.EvilGnome: EvilGnome is a Linux malware masquerading as a Gnome shell extension and designed to spy on unsuspecting Linux desktops. EvilGnome’s functionalities include desktop screenshots, file stealing, allowing capturing audio recording from the user’s microphone, and the ability to download and execute further modules.  Old threat, recently used by threat actor Garmaredon to attack Ukraine. https://therecord.media/a-deeper-look-at-hacking-groups-and-malware- targeting-ukraine/

Threat Actors.Curious Gorge: Curious Gorge, is a threat actor group that researchers attribute to China’s PLA SSF, it has conducted campaigns against government and military organizations in Ukraine, Russia, Kazakhstan, and Mongolia.  Newly found TA group. https://blog.google/threat-analysis-group/tracking-cyber-activity-eastern- europe/
Threat Actors.UNC3381: UNC3381 is a financially motivated threat group, which is suspected to be FIN7 with low confidence. Throughout their campaigns, UNC3381 has used nearly identical Quickbooks-themed invoice lures and leveraged the branding of the compromised account that they were sent from, providing additional legitimacy for their phishes.  Financially motivated threat group suspected be associated with FIN7 https://www.mandiant.com/resources/evolution-of-fin7
Threat Actors.Armageddon: Armageddon is a Russian state-sponsored threat actor that has been attacking Ukraine since at least 2014 and is thought to be affiliated with the FSB (Russian Federal Security Service). It attacked Ukraine via the distribution of e-mails on “Information on war criminals of the Russian Federation” among government agencies of Ukraine to deliver a PowerShell script in 2022 during the Russian invasion of Ukraine. According to a thorough technical study provided by the Ukrainian secret agency in November 2021, Armageddon has conducted at least 5,000 cyber-attacks against 1,500 vital businesses in Ukraine.  Ukraine detects Armageddon phishing attacks related to Russia. https://therecord.media/ukrainian-cert-details-russia-linked-phishing-attacks- targeting-government-officials/
Threat Actors.CHERNOVITE: CHERNOVITE is a Russian threat actor who is infamous for attacking industrial control systems. They are highly knowledgeable of ICS protocols, devices, and how to apply this knowledge to achieve an effect. It’s likely that they have a budget for acquiring devices in order to test their toolset. CHERNOVITE is highly motivated, skilled in software development methods, well versed in ICS protocols and intrusion techniques, and well-funded.  PIPEDREAM: CHERNOVITE’S EMERGING MALWARE TARGETING INDUSTRIAL CONTROL SYSTEMS https://hub.dragos.com/hubfs/116-Whitepapers/Dragos_ChernoviteWP_v2b. pdf?hsLang=en
Threat Actors.NB65: NB65 is a hacking group that emerged breaching Russian entities, stealing their data, and leaking it online, warning that the attacks are due to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine in 2022. The Russian entities claimed to have been attacked by the hacking group include document management operator Tensor, Russian space agency Roscosmos, and VGTRK, the state-owned Russian Television and Radio broadcaster. NB65 has been seen using Conti’s leaked ransomware to deploy these attacks.  | Who is NB 65? Hackers use Conti’s leaked ransomware to attack Russian companies https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/hackers-use-contis-leaked- ransomware-to-attack-russian-companies/
Threat Actors.OldGremlin: OldGremlin is the only Russian-speaking ransomware operator that violates the unspoken rule about not working within Russia and post-Soviet countries. They carry out multistage targeted attacks on Russian companies and banks using sophisticated tactics and techniques similar to those employed by APT groups. As with similar groups that target foreign entities, OldGremlin can be classed as part of Big Game Hunting, which brings together ransomware operators targeting large corporate networks.  | Who is Old Gremin? Russian-speaking ransomware gang OldGremlin resumes attacks in Russia. https://blog.group-ib.com/oldgremlin_comeback
Threat Actors.Haskers Gang: Haskers Gang is a crimeware-related threat actor group active since at least January 2020, consisting of a small number of original members. Their activity ranges from developing methods for stealing confidential information to cryptocurrency mining, remote access, and the development of so-called “crypters” to avoid the detection of malware by security and antivirus software. The core members of this crimeware group are likely located in Eastern Europe, and many of the announcements and other communications are written in Russian. The threat actor uses collaborative platforms such as Telegram and Discord to distribute updates, share tooling, and otherwise coordinate activities.  | What do you know about Haskers? Threat Spotlight: “Haskers Gang” Introduces New ZingoStealer https://blog.talosintelligence.com/2022/04/haskers-gang-zingostealer.html
Threat Actors.Conference Crew Group: Conference Crew group is a Chinese threat actor that has retooled and pivoted its strategies to better align with China’s overall strategy since early 2021. This plan focuses on supporting the nation’s Belt and Road Initiative, its long-term policy, and investment program. The plan also focuses on markets like technology, financials, energy, telecommunications, and healthcare.  CHINESE CYBER ESPIONAGE APT. https://duo.com/decipher/chinese-cyber-espionage-apts-refocus-strategy
Threat Actors.BeagleBoyz: BeagleBoyz represents a subset of HIDDEN COBRA activity. The BeagleBoyz overlap to varying degrees with groups tracked by the cybersecurity industry as Lazarus and are responsible for the FASTCash ATM cashouts reported in October 2018, fraudulent abuse of compromised bank-operated SWIFT system endpoints since at least 2015, and lucrative cryptocurrency thefts. The BeagleBoyz, an element of the North Korean government’s Reconnaissance General Bureau, have likely been active since at least 2014. As opposed to typical cybercrime, the group likely conducts well-planned, disciplined, and methodical cyber operations more akin to careful espionage activities. Their malicious cyber operations have netted hundreds of millions of U.S. dollars and are likely a major source of funding for the North Korean regime. The group has always used a calculated approach, which allows them to sharpen their tactics, techniques, and procedures while evading detection. Over time, their operations have become increasingly complex and destructive. The tools and implants employed by this group are consistently complex and demonstrate a strong focus on effectiveness and operational security.  | Information on Beagle Boyz Threat Actor that overlaps to varying degrees with groups tracked by the cybersecurity industry as Lazarus. https://www.cisa.gov/uscert/ncas/alerts/aa20-239a
Threat Actors.Pompilus: A sub-set of infamous threat actor group Lazarus.  Sub-set of Lazarus activity. https://symantec-enterprise-blogs.security.com/blogs/threat-intelligence/ lazarus-dream-job-chemical
Threat Actors.Ransom Cartel: After REvil announced retirement from creating havoc in the cyber world, another threat actor group ‘Ransom Cartel’ made its debut and was highly similar to REvil. Files encrypted by Ransom Cartel’s crypto-locking malware, for example, when viewed with a hex editor, have footers that “look” like files encrypted by REvil, even down to the placement of the checksum used to check for errors in a file, Whether any former members of REvil are part of Ransom Cartel remains unknown.  REvil’s TOR sites come alive to redirect to new ransomware operation https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/revils-tor-sites-come-alive- to-redirect-to-new-ransomware-operation/
Threat Actors.Water Roc: Water Roc has been active since at least March 2020. Water Roc, also known as the Nefilim group, is notable in how it targets multibillion-dollar organizations using ransomware while trying to maximize payouts using double extortion. Not only does this group make computer networks unusable and files inaccessible, but it also relentlessly releases stolen sensitive victim information and in some cases continues to leak more data for many months after the initial compromise.  | Threat actor Nefilim REvil’s TOR sites come alive to redirect to new ransomware operation https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/revils-tor-sites-come-alive- to-redirect-to-new-ransomware-operation/
Threat Actors.TeslaCrypt Ransomware Group: TeslaCrypt was a ransomware trojan. It is now defunct, and its master key was released by the developers. In its early forms, TeslaCrypt targeted game-play data for specific computer games. Newer variants of the malware also affect other file types. TeslaCrypt encrypted files and asked for ransom ($500). Amongst other types of target files, it tried to infect typical gaming files: game saves, user profiles, recoded replays, etc. TeslaCrypt did not encrypt files that are larger than 268 MB.  | Information on TeslaCrypt Inactive Ransomware gang, added in the KB https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/revils-tor-sites-come-alive- to-redirect-to-new-ransomware-operation/
Threat Actors.Altahrea Team: Altahrea Team is a pro-Iran hacking group who targeted the website of the Israel Airports Authority. The group said its actions were “revenge” for the assassination by the United States on January 3rd, 2020 of Iranian Quds Force commander Qassem Soleimani and Abu Mahdi Al-Muhandes, the commander of the pro-Iranian Popular Mobilization Forces Shi’ite militias in Iraq. Altahrea Team / AL- | What is Altahrea? Pro-Iran hackers target Israel Airports Authority website. https://www.israelhayom.com/2022/04/24/report-pro-iran-hackers-target- israel-airports-authority-website/
Threat Actors.UNC2639: UNC2639 was first identified exploiting multiple zero-day vulnerabilities in Microsoft Exchange in early March 2021. This actor uses these vulnerabilities to deploy webshells including CHINACHOPPER. UNC2639 / UNC- | Threat actor UNC-2639 | Details on UNC 2639 Old threat actor active in March 2021, added to the KB https://www.mandiant.com/resources/unc-groups
Threat Actors.Nemesis Kitten: An Iranian state-sponsored threat actor, infamous for exploiting Log4Shell vulnerability in their malicious campaigns. Nemesis Kitten attempt both disruptive and destructive attacks.  Old threat actor, who had no public information previously, was added to the KB. https://www.zdnet.com/article/khonsari-ransomware-iranian-group-nemesis- kitten-seen-exploiting-log4j/
Threat Actors.Tarnished Gauntlet: An Iranian threat actor group that came out as a hacktivist group but according to researchers, are moving from hacktivist personas to crime personas, so it can organically capitalize on ransomware’s disruptive capabilities while also allowing them to blend in with a large volume of new criminal activity.  Old threat actor, who had no public information previously, was added to the KB. https://www.csoonline.com/article/3640406/cyberwars-global-players-its-not- always-russia-or-china.html
Threat Actors.Spectral Kitten: An Iranian threat actor group that came out as a hacktivist group but according to researchers is moving from hacktivist personas to crime personas, so it can organically capitalize on ransomware’s disruptive capabilities while also allowing them to blend in with a large volume of new criminal activity.  Old threat actor, who had no public information previously, was added to the KB. https://www.csoonline.com/article/3640406/cyberwars-global-players-its-not- always-russia-or-china.html
Threat Actors.Hive0117: Hive0117, likely a financially motivated cybercriminal group, since February 2022, designed a campaign to deliver the fileless malware variant dubbed DarkWatchman. Hive0117 was also behind multiple emails that were sent in mid-February 2022 to individual users, including a state-owned communication company based in Lithuania, a prominent Industrial Enterprise in Estonia, and several electronic and telecommunication businesses located in Russia. In some cases, the emails were targeting company owners, as well as individuals in leadership positions associated with Dispatch Services and Sales. Targeted organizations could be of high value to criminal actors given the targets’ potential trusted access to a wide, and distributed client base. Hive0117 / Hive 0117 / Hive- | Threat actor Hive 0117 | Information on Hive-0117 Hive0117 Continues Fileless Malware Delivery in Eastern Europe https://securityintelligence.com/posts/hive00117-fileless-malware-delivery- eastern-europe/
Threat Actors.Hackers of Savior: On May 21, 2020, a hacktivist group going by the name ‘Hackers of Savior’ launched a defacing campaign targeting thousands of Israeli websites. Their Twitter handle says, “We are doing our best to take back the occupied land of Palestine from the Zionist occupiers with help of all the freedom seekers around the world.” The group originates from Iran and plans targeted campaigns against Israel.  | Who is the Spider Team? Iranian Hackers Claim They’ve Hit the Bank of Israel - but ‘No Proof,’ Cyber Authority Says https://www.radware.com/security/ddos-threats-attacks/threat-advisories- attack-reports/hackers-of-savior/
Threat Actors.JollyFrog: JollyFrog comes under the umbrella of threat actor group TA410. JollyFrog uses only generic malware families such as Korplug (aka PlugX) and QuasarRAT.  | Information on Jolly Frog ESET researchers reveal a detailed profile of TA410: they believe this cyberespionage umbrella group consists of three different teams using different toolsets. https://www.welivesecurity.com/2022/04/27/lookback-ta410-umbrella- cyberespionage-ttps-activity/

FlowingFrog uses Royal Road RTF documents, a first-stage implant called Tendyron, and a very complex second- stage backdoor called FlowCloud. Its targets are Universities, foreign diplomatic missions of a South Asian country in China and mining companies.  | Details on Flowing Frog ESET researchers reveal a detailed profile of TA410: they believe this cyberespionage umbrella group consists of three different teams using different toolsets. https://www.welivesecurity.com/2022/04/27/lookback-ta410-umbrella- cyberespionage-ttps-activity/

TA579 / TA 579 / TA- | Anything on TA 579 | What do you know about TA-579? Threat Actors.LookingFrog: LookingFrog uses a first-stage backdoor called X4, and LookBack as a second- stage payload. LookingFrog targets Diplomatic missions, charity, government, and industrial manufacturing industries. Attackers linked to LookingFrog exploited Microsoft SharePoint servers in 2019 to gain code execution, probably by leveraging CVE-2019-0604. They then dropped an ASPX webshell that was used to install other malicious components. These were either dropped directly via the webshell or downloaded from a remote server using certutil.exe, a known LOLBin.  | Who is Looking Frog? ESET researchers reveal a detailed profile of TA410: they believe this cyberespionage umbrella group consists of three different teams using different toolsets. https://www.welivesecurity.com/2022/04/27/lookback-ta410-umbrella- cyberespionage-ttps-activity/
Threat Actors.TA578: TA578, a threat actor that researchers have been tracking since May of 2020. TA578 has previously been observed in email-based campaigns delivering Ursnif, IcedID, KPOT Stealer, Buer Loader, BazaLoader, and Cobalt Strike. TA578 / TA 578 / TA- | Tell me about TA 578 | Who is TA-578 Threat actor deploying malicious campaign used malware BUMBLEBEE. https://www.proofpoint.com/us/blog/threat-insight/bumblebee-is-still- transforming
Threat Actors.TALONITE: Researchers began tracking the TALONITE activity group in July 2019 with operations focusing on initial access compromises in the United States (U.S.) electric sector. The group uses phishing techniques with either malicious documents or executables. TALONITE uses two custom malware families that both feature multiple components known as LookBack and FlowCloud. TALONITE focuses on subverting and taking advantage of trust with phishing lures focusing on engineering-specific themes and concepts, malware that abuses otherwise legitimate binaries or modifies such binaries to include additional functionality, and a combination of owned and compromised network infrastructure.  Threat actor who uses malware LookBack and RoyalRoad in its campaign. https://www.dragos.com/blog/industry-news/new-ics-threat-activity-group- talonite/
